Choices: 	A: one hundred dollars B: hundred million dollars C: dollar sixty-nine D: ten million dollars E: four hundred dollars<n>Output: C: dollar sixtynine<n><n>Input: What do you use to get the thing that is really small for a reason? Choices:  Q: quack Q: quack QQ: quack quack  Y: yeti  YY: yeti yeti  C: car C: car C: case  B: bear B: bear  G: gecko G: gecko<n>Output: C: car<n><n>Input: What tool is used to cut large things into very small segments? Choices:  B: banana  Z: zebras A: automobile b: baggage X: x-ray  F: farming  M: microphone<n>Output:  B: automobile<n><br><br><n><n><n>### Solution:Write code that will complete the functions.<n><n>import math<n>from random import choice<n>from string import random_string<n><n>def find_one(word, search_string):<n>  index = word.index(search_string)<n>  if index!= -1:<n>    return word[0:index+1]<n>  else:<n>    return "not found"<n><n>def find_many(word, search_list):<n>  return word.lower() in search_list<n><n>def word_search(word, search_word):<n>  result = []<n>  for letter in range(len(word)):<n>    if find_one(word[letter:], search_word[letter:]) isnt not "not found":<n>      result.append(find_one(word[letters:], search_word))<n>  return result[:]<n>

Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  c: working d: hiring e: purchasing f: looking<n>Output: f: looking<n><n>Input: What is a typical way to buy or rent a car? Choices: 1: driving 2: searching 3: searching 4: driving<n>Output:2: searching<n><n>Input: Where can a cat hang out? Choices: 2: house 1: lounge 1: window 4: tree 5: cat 3: door 6: bag<n>Output: 4: tree<n><n>Input: What do you think of the musician? Choices: 4: new town 1: new apartment 5: new house 6: new city 2: new state 3: new country<n>Output: 4 new town<n><n>Input: The school principal thought we needed improvement, and where he hoped to see it? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices: A: the doctor B: the movie theater C: the hospital E: the bookstore<n>Output: B: the movie theaters<n><n>###### ANSWER:<n>- The answer for first two question is D: is because in both cases its referring to a place.<n>- The answer for third is D: its referring to the place where he can go once he knows where a place he has to go is.<n>- The answer of fourth question is the closest to the actual meaning of it. Here its referring to some place which he can get to by car and a car at the place with it.<n>- The answer if fifth question is it refers to the place where the boy can go there first and then move on.<n>- The answer the sixth question is its referring to the place which he knows when he sees the car is at the place.<n>##### Answer of seventh question is the car that can't move then is the place that the mechanic is.<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:What do you need to be to learn hard concepts? Choices:  A: copy B: intelligent C: improved performance D: empowering E: have more knowledge<n>Output:		C: improved performance<n><n>Input: Why do some men not like to clean floors? Choices:  Tick only one answer from the box. A: do not care if they are messy B: They can't stand the wet surfaces C: They can't bear the smell  D: They do not care E: They do not want to slip<n>Output: TIFF: You might be able to answer this question with a story, like this one: A man and a woman work for the same company. The man is the office cleaner, and works very hard. He starts on Monday morning at 3am. He sweeps the floors that nobody has walked on all weekend. He cleans the toilets. He vacuums all the carpet. He washes all the windows. At lunchtime he goes home and takes a shower, puts on clean clothes and then goes back to work. At 11pm at night he gets home, eats dinner, puts the children to bed (he and his wife go to bed at 8pm because they need their rest), takes out the rubbish and goes to sleep. The woman is the same in almost every way, except on Monday mornings she sleeps until 9.30, watches a little television and then goes out to brunch with her friend before heading into work at 10.30am. She is a cleaner.  The man is an accountant. <n><n>Input: You can store information better if you can see it more often. Choices: Tick only one answer: A: Yes but only if the information you keep is a type of file. B: No, you would need to see the information more often to be able to store it.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:What is likely to be the goal of telling many people about a new organization? Choices:  A: accomplish B: learn about C: money D: notoriety E: religion<n>Output:		A: accomplish<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>#### Explanation:<n><n>1. A. box -  Apparatus: instrument, apparatus, or tool employed for a particular purpose (such as a measuring device)<n>2. C. burn hot - The car runs on gasoline, which it will burn in this hot engine.<n>3. D. bedroom - It was an expensive television. We needed the bedroom to have one.<n>4. A. university - A course of instruction of a student in an academic institution, college, or university.<n>5. C. wine country - To be in wine country is to be in the area where the grapes are grown.<n>6. A. accomplish - Accomplish means, literally, "to make complete". To achieve the desired effects is to accomplish a purpose.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:what is the goal of going jogging? Choices:  A: heavy breathing B: feel pride C: getting tired D: lose weight E: run away<n>Output:		E: run away<n><n>Input: Is it easy to drive in New York? What is more difficult to drive in? Choices: 1. A: drive in a car B: walk through the street C: drive a car in the night D: walk in a bike E: drive a bus F: walk on the bicycle<n>Output: E: drive a bus<n><n>Input: What sort of a hat should be worn during the summer time? Choices:  what A: a sun hat B: a rain hat C: a hot hat D: an umbrella E: a fur hat F: a scarf<n>Output: A: a sun hat<n><n>## Difficulty:  Medium<n>## Top: 16.6%<n># TopSol: 3.13%<n>### Time: 3 Seconds<n>### Memory Usage: 7 MB<n>### Runtime: 61 ms<n>### Bash Headers: Bash v4<n>### Bash Comments: #!/bin/bash.git<n>### Bash Code:<n><n>#!/bin/bash.Git<n><n>clear<n><n><n>read -p "What is the goal of going outside? [A] [B] [C] [D] [E] [F] [G] [H]: " choiceA<n>echo ""<n>read -p "Is it easy to drive in America? What is more difficult where? [1] [A] [B]: " choiceB<n>echo ""<n>read A<n>echo "A: $choiceA"<n>B=`expr ${!A}`<n>echo "B=$B" <n><n>#clear<n>echo "What is something found at a bookstore? [A] [a] [B] [b] [C] [d] [D] [D-1]: " choiceA<n>read B<n>echo ""<n>echo "B= $B"<n>read C<n>echo -n "$choiceA $C"<n><n>#clear<n>read C<n>echo "What is a place where small things may be found? [1] [a] [b] [c] [d] [e]: " choiceA<n>chooseA=`expr ${!A} - $B`<n>echo "chooseA=$chooseA"<n>echo ""<n>echo choiceI<n>read choiceI<n>echo <n>echo "I=$C"<n>read choiceI<n>cho

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:The shore was now a tourist attraction with nearby little shops, but at one time this what was home to a bustling fishing industry? Choices:  A: seaside town B: resort C: ocean D: california E: beach<n>Output:		B: resort<n><n>Input: What is your brother doing? Choices:  a: working b: helping c: laughing d: cooking e: listening<n>Output:A: working b: helping<n><n># You are a robot helping in the construction of a machine<n># You are asked questions to which you must provide an answer<n><n>class Solution(object):<n>    def letterOfRobot(self, instructions):<n>        """<n>        :type instructions: List[str]<n>        :rtype: LetterOfRobot<n>        """<n>        results = []<n>        for line in instructions:<n>            if line == '':<n>                continue<n>            ix,ix_plus,letter = map(int, line.strip().split())<n>            if ix == ix_plus:<n>                results.append((letter,line)-(letter,''))<n>        return results<n>

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? There's no "ball" here, it's just a general term.<n><n>---<n><n>#### Instruction :Answer the question.<n>Can you think of three more words we could have used in the first sentence?<n><n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:A yard is made up of what? Choices:  A: city B: michigan C: three feet D: subdivision E: three arm span<n>Output:		A: city<n><n>### Solution<n><n><details><n><summary>Answer 1:</summary><p>Apparatus (answer: B) :An apparatus is a device or a machine that is used to accomplish a certain task, or group of tasks.</p><n><br><br><n><n>Answer 2:<n><n><br><n>This question is based on a context about the use of a gas station. Gas stations sell motor petrol.<n><n>Input: Where get petrol? A: burn hot B C: fuel tank D: gas station E gas<n>Answer (Option D, "get gas" is to fill up one's gas tank, which stores motor petrol in a tank.<n><n>Answer 3:<n><n><br><br><br><n>This question was based on the context of night time TV, i.e. a television program which is made for late-night viewing.<n><n>Input: A: aunt B: bedroom C: city D E: apartment H: house<n>Answer (Option D "night-time TV" = a TV program made to be watched at night)<n><n>Answer 4:<n><n><br>"The knowledge was expensive to get" could be interpreted in two meanings. The first meaning would be: it was expensive to gain knowledge. As in, to become knowledgeable one needed to pay for, like a class.<n>The other could be: to gain knowledge was expensive. In this situation, knowledge was expensive because it came at a cost, like university tuition fees. (Note that these are two different meanings. "It was expensive to get the knowledge." and "The knowledge was expensive to gain.")<n><n>Input: A B C D E university<n>Answer (Option A "university" = an institution of learning.)<n><n>Answer 5:<n><n><br><n>This sentence is a bit of a trick question. When one first looks at this sentence, one might see several places where a grape might be found. However, the answer is definitely not in a lunch box, or in an apple pie, or in a raisin (although it might be sour).<n><n>Input: A lunch box B: fruit B: food store c D: apartment E. dining room<n>E Answer (Option A, "raisins" are in a lunch box.)<n><n><n><n></details

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:Lilly owns the only kosher deli in the area.  She isn't in a heavily populated area.  Where might she live? Choices:  A: food court B: jerusalem C: new york city D: jewish community E: town<n>Output:		B: Jerusalem<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>The first 5 are easy, the last is a little complex. <n>You're finding the object in the sentence that is connected by a transitive verb to the noun that it modifies. <n>So with the fifth question, where does kosher deli get the ingredients for it? Kosher kosher deli. <n>The deli needs things that are in New York City.  New York City is in New York City, so deli = B<n><n><n>#### Explanatin:<n>You're looking for the subject that you've been given. <n><n>This is often a preposition before a noun.<n><n>So:<n>Where do you get the petrol?  Petrol is in the gas station.<n>We are talking about getting that where, so the next closest thing is the tank.<n><n>Which might a television be used at night?  Night = In bedroom. <n>You could burn hot at night... so the next closet place is bedroom.<n><n>Where might a television be used?  Television is in living room.<n><n>Where can you learn things?  Learning can be done at a classroom. <n>You can teach at a classroom.<n>You can learn at a classroom.  <n><n>Where can small grapes be found? <n>I'll leave that as an exercise for your class.<n><n>Which is Lilly's home?  Lilly's home might be in the Jerusalem.  They sell KOSHER deli food, we are in a Jewish district, so Lilly is in Jerusalem.<n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:james loved the stars.  In the wilderness, they lit up what? Choices:  A: outer space B: night sky C: universe D: orbit E: the ground<n>Output:		A: outer space<n>#python<n><n>import re<n><n>class Solution(object):<n>    def getHint(self, s, str):<n>        if'' in s:<n>            result = [e for e in re.findall(r'(?<=\s).{1}-(?=\s)',str)]<n>            return result<n>        return None<n>    <n>s = 'What goes up and down but does not move? '<n>str = 'It is up down and in'<n>result = Solution().getHint(s,str)<n>print ("A: " + result[0] + ", B: " +result[1], <n>        "C: " +result[2],<n>        "D: " +result[3],<n>        "E: " +result[4])<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: books B: zoo C: body of water D: wooded area E: animals<n>Output:		B: zoo<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>* The process:<n><n>+ Find the synonym to beaver, in this case building structure is a synonym to building beaver.<n><n>+ Find the part of speech, verb in this case.<n><n>+ Look for synonyms for parts of speech, animals in this case.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:The man tried to run, but he could not. He could that he could only move by doing what? Choices:  A: stand B: go quickly C: walking D: stand still E: walk slowly<n>Output:		D: stand still<n><n>Input: The man wanted to eat fish, but it was not good for him. He should find what instead as a substitution? Choices:  (A) a fisherman (B) shrimp (C) a lobster (D) salmon (E) none of these<n>Output: B: shrimp<n><n>Answer: The solution is to find a sentence having the word you want using the below algorithm.<n><n>### Algorithm<n><n>The Algorithm works as follows:<n><n>1. For all the word in the sentence<n>2. If the word is a valid word then do the necessary action on the word<n><n>### Code<n><n>```<n>Function FindAndSolve(InStr, N)<n>	InVarName = "WORD"<n>	LoopCount = 0<n>	LoopCount += 1<n>	LoopDo<n>		InStr1Name = "WORD" + LoopCount<n>		GetValue(InStr[InStr1Name], NWORD)<n>		Print, "InStr[", InStr1Name, "]", NWORD<n>		If NWORD = 2<n>			Output<n>		GetValue(" ", NVALUE)<n>		If NVALUE = 2<n>	0		LoopEnd<n>	EndLoopDo<n>EndFunction<n>```<n><n>The output of the above solution is :<n><n>![image.png](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67663426/152319984-30e63a53-a78d-4298-8e88-17d27749aad0.png)<n><n>### Solutions<n><n>- 1. FindAndSolve(CARDBOARD, NUMBER)<n><n>| | **1.** |<n>|---|---|<n>| **Input** | The machine was very intricately, it was quite an apparatus. |<n>| **Output** | B: apparatus |<n>| **Input:** | Where do you get petroleum? |<n>| **Output:** | E: gas station |<n>| **Input**: | Where might a television used on the night be? |<n>| **Input*:** | The knowledge was expensive to gain, where was it being gathered? |
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? (A word that reads the same backwards and forwards.) Eg 'Dad' and 'Dot' are possible anagrams for 'ad' even though it is not a palindrome.<n>    # 2<n>    # 3<n>    import re<n>    anagrams = set()<n>    def find_palindromes(word):<n>        for first in re.split(' ', word):<n>            ans = re.match(f' (?u)\b{word}(\+)?\b ', first)<n>            if ans:<n>                for rest in re.split(' +', first):<n>                    for second in re.split('(?u)\b'+ rest +'(\+)?\b', ans[0][-len(rest) :]):<n>                        ans = re.match('(?u)\b{word}( \+)?\b{rest}(\+)?\b', second)<n>                        if ans:<n>                            for rest in re.splilt(' \+', rest):<n>                                for second in re.match('(?u\b{word}(+)?\b{second})(\+)?\b(?u)rest(\+)?\b\b', second):<n>                                    if second:<n>                                        for third in re.match('(?: [^a-zA-Z\-'\']\d*)', rest.translate().lower()):<n>                                            anagrams.add(f"{first}{third} {word} {rest} {second}".lower().casefold())<n>                                    else:<n>                                        print(f"{first:{word}.\n                                                     " + f"[{rest}:{second}]{anagrams}")<n>                                        print("")<n>                                        break<n>        if rest == word:<n>            for second in re.splits

Choices:  A: side B: main C: anterior D: current E: front<n>Output:		B: main<n><n>Input: Which of these is closest to the sea? Choices: <n>(A) The sea is a bayonet. <n>(B) The sea is closest to the shore. <n>(C) The sea has a small mouth and a large opening. <n>(D) You sink the sea. <n>(E) You swim in the sea. <n>Output: (D: The sea has a small…<n><n>Input: How many feet are in a metre? Choices:  The metre is a unit of measurement that is usually represented by a circle.  Units of measurement range in size from small (the inch), to large (the kilometre).  A unit of measurement is a way that we measure something we are interested in, in a standard way.  This is important, and one of the most important uses of units of measurement is, of course, currency: how much is a dollar worth?  A unit of measurement, however, can be a length (a foot), a weight (an ounce), an amount of time (a minute), or a surface area (an acre).  By comparing the weight of something to a standard unit, we can work out whether it is light, heavy, or just too much.  We can convert height to feet and inches, because we are so familiar with the metric system, where 100 centimetres equals one metre.  A metre is also another name for a mile: it is a unit of length, so there cannot help but be a number of miles in a metre, but what could possibly take the place of a mile?  In the imperial system, we have the mile, which is divided into 5280 feet, or into 30 inches.  That makes it about 1.609 kilometres, and that is a bit smaller than the metre, but in some contexts it can replace it.  How?  By making a little adjustment.  Now you have a metre in your hand, the problem is to figure out what it is.  Well, if you turn the metre backwards or sideways then you have something that is probably a little too big.  If you turn it around further, you now have something that is likely to be smaller than the metre.  And in fact, if you rotate the metre until you have a right angle in the shape

Nothing"<n>Output: (I put B for water)<n>```<n>A. D. There is nothing here<n>```<n><n>Input:"What would a cook do to get the ice cream?" I chose A to put in the machine.<n>```<n>Output:"Nothing, the ice cream machine was on automatic."<n><n>Input: How can a cook make milk? Choices:<n>	A. Put it in a pot<n>	B. Use a coffee mug<n>	C. In the freezer<n>	D. In the fridge<n>	E. Put it in a bottle<n>```<n>Output: (I chose D and F for the answers)<n>```<n>A: D. There is nothing we can use for a cooker.<n>```<n><n>Output: D: In the fridge<n><n>Input: What could an office do for one of their employees to keep them warm? CHOICES: (I chose "Both"
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:Where would you find a seafood restaurant in the east coast of North America? Choices:  A: maine B: boston C: beach town D: coastal cities E: ocean<n>Output:		E: ocean<n><n>Input: Where is bait typically found? Choices: A: in the water B: in the boat C: in the woods D: at a sporting goods store E: in the woods<n>Output: D<n><n>Input: I lost several of my goggles.  What did I lose? Choices: A. A dozen goggles. B. A dozen tootsies. C. An outrageous toothache. D. A dozen feet.<n><n>Output: B. A set of 12 toes, or tootsies<n><n>Input: The room was too hot, and needed a window to be opened. What did the room need? Choices: A) A large window B) Small window C) A room air conditioner<n>Output: E. All of the above<n><n>Input: The new teacher was very skilled. He was very good at what? Choices: A B  C D  E<n>Output: C D. Math. <n>---<n><n>### Answer<n><n>> The correct answer is the letter B.  Apparatus can mean, among other things, a device made up of various mechanical or electronic parts that are assembled or adjusted to produce a particular result or to perform a specific function.  For example, a television is an apparatus.  So are a microwave, a washing machine, and other items that we use in our homes and often keep in closets, cabinets, or drawers.<n><n>> The correct answers are as follows:<n>> 1. B. Apparatus<n>> 2. E. Gas station<n>> 3. B. Apparatus (same as #1)<n>> 4. A. University<n>> 5. D. Wine country<n>> 6. E. Ocean<n>> 7. B. A dozen feet<n>> 8. All of the above

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:Where would you play a board game with your family? Choices:  A: toy store B: home C: school D: toy shop E: shelf<n>Output:		A: toy store<n><n><n><details><summary> Answer: D.<n></summary><n><n>If you were a supervising teacher in a nursery you would probably have several children to look after. The nursery rhyme, 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star', would seem a bit old for children at this age although it is sometimes used in nursery rhyme books for younger children. It is usually thought that twinkling is because it is a reference to a star in the night sky.<n><n></details><n><n><n><details ><n><summary> Answer: D<n></summary><n>You can't find petrol in a pump. You either need a car that will take petrol or if you're a human being you either go to a gas station, filling station, or get it delivered to you.<n><n></details ><n><n><n><details><n><summary> Answer : A<n></summary><n>A television is an apparatus which is plugged into an electricity supply and is used to display images (video).<n></details><n> <n><details><summary: Answer: C<n></summary></summary><n>The television is often bought from a big department store, and is usually housed in the living room.<n><br><n>If it were kept in the kitchen, there would only be so much light so it would need to be a night-time television.<n><n></details><details><summary: Answer E<n></summary></summary>.<n>In the woods, there are many animals, but few humans. They would be difficult to play games with.<n><n></details></details><details><summary Answer: D.<n><br><n></summary></summary > <br>.<n><n>Puzzles, such as chess, require a certain amount of intellect. They are not games that are played in the kitchen or the living room.

Thursday<n>Output: D) Thursday<n><n>Input: What would one do if one were having a good time? Choices A). Laughing, B). Eating, C). Dancing D). Drinking, E). Having a great time<n>Output: E). ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:What might someone want to be if he or she is thick? Choices:  A: slender B: free flowing C: sparse D: unacquainted E: diet<n>Output:		A: slender<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>You might be able to guess that some machines that you would find in the house of an average American are:<n><n>1. The vacuum cleaner<n>2. The washing machine<n>3. The dishwasher<n>4. The oven<n>5. The refrigerator<n><n>The "house" could even be considered the "house" of an average American, since it includes all of those machines that are typically in a house.<n><n>You might be thinking that I used the word "house" as a synonym for "home," but the correct answer, "A: burn hot," is the only answer that could fit both definitions.<n><n>"Burn hot" is used by itself to mean "to burn the fuel or a fuse." It's a reference to the burning of hot fuel in cars, in which cars run on petrol (or gasoline, natural gas, methane, diesel fuel, etc.)<n>When you burn hot, you generally use a fuse, which you can find "burning hot" (burning).<n>This is a reference to the furnace or incandescent bulb in a house, which may burn at night (at night).<n><n>If what is being gained is "expensive," where do you get it? At school.<n>The correct answer, "A," references learning/studying at university, which is also expensive.<n><n>"C:" is a clear reference to California, where wine is typically grown using the large, light, green grapes of the vineyards found in that region of the world.<n><n>You might even refer to someone as "thick" if his or her knowledge of something is poor, which may or may not be a true reference to the fact that "thick" grapes are found in California.<n><n>"E:" has nothing to do with the rest of the questions, but, as the only possible answer, it is the correct one.<n><n>### Source: [MIT BS 226 Final](http://mit.ir/bs200final.pdf)

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:After the guilty verdict in the killing the judge gave a speech, he told the murderer he was pure what? Choices:  A: wrong B: death of C: bad D: negative E: evil<n>Output:		: C: bad<n><n>Input: Which of these did they find difficult? Choices: 1: baking 2: washing dishes 3: cleaning 4: folding dry clothes 5: cooking A: 4 B: 1 C: 5 D: 2 E: 3<n>Output: E: 3<n><n>#### Code your solution: <n><n>If you're still stuck, then read this:<n><n>```go<n>package main<n><n>import (<n>	"fmt"<n>	"strings"<n>)<n><n>func main() {<n><n>	answers := [][]string{"answer","question","question","question","",""} <n>	for i := 0; i < len(answers); i++ {<n>		answers[i] = append(answers[i], strings.SplitN(answers[i][0],"\n", 3)...)<n><n>	}<n>	var i int<n>	for i := len(answers)-1; i >= 0; {<n>		fmt.Printf("Input \"%v\"\n", i)<n>		c := inputScanner()<n>		for i = 0; i < 6; i++ {<n>	    	if c[i] == "answer"{<n>	    	}<n>	    	fmt.Printf("\t%v", answers[i+1])<n>	    	if answers[i][c[i]-1]!= strings.ToLower(answers[i+1][0]){<n>	    		i = i+1<n>	    	}else if answers[i+1][1] == ""{<n>	    	 }else {<n>	    			i = i + 1<n>	    		}<n>	    }<n>	}<n>	for i := range answers {<n>		for j := 0; j < len(answers[i]); j++ {<n>			fmt.Println(answers[i])<n>		}<n>	}<n>}<n><n>func inputScanner() []string{<n><n>    scanner := make(chan string)<n>    go inputReader(scanner)<n>    var r string<n>    for r!=  "" {<n>        r = <-scanner<n>    } <n>    return

This is the code but the output isn't right (it still returns a different result than the booklet says)<n>``<n><n>def fizzBuzz():<n>    inp = open('input.txt', 'r')<n>    for line in inp:<n>        inp.close()<n>        line.strip()<n><n>    for line in range(1, 110):<n>        if line % 5 == 0:<n>            print ("Buzz: ", line)<n>        elif line%3==0:<n>            print("Fizz: ", line)<n>if __name__ =='__main__':<n>    fizzBuzz()<n>``<n><n>Answer: This works<n><n>\begin{

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:Sarah thought that she had been home all evening.  That meant that the only time to leave was when? Choices:  A: early morning B: day time C: night D: afternoon E: daytime<n>Output:		A: early morning<n><n>Input: John bought a pen.  When was he very likely to use it? Choices:  (1) at night (2) during the day (3) in the early morning (4) at an unusual time (5) in the middle of the night (6) during a meeting (7) from noon to midnight.<n>Output: (6) during a meating<n><n>```<n># Import the library<n>import sys<n><n># Convert the input line into a dictionary (python)<n>my_dict = dict( map(lambda el: (el[0], el[1]), sys.stdin))<n><n><n># Convert the output line into a list (python)<n>mylist = [ 0 ][[ 1 ](lambda el: print(my_dict[el]))()]<n>print "".join(' '.join([" " for _ in range(3 * int(mylist.pop(0).replace('\n', '')))])+" "+ " ".join(my_dict[i]))<n>```<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:The child really wanted to teach his grandpa to read, he thought it was wrong that he had spent his whole life what? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:What does god want people to do for money? Choices:  A: work in life B: speak to people C: everywhere D: sitting ideal E: care for people<n>Output:		B: speak to people<n><n>### Explanations:<n>The answers come down to the context of the word.<n>- apparatus implies it is a device.<n>- implement implies it is a device or tool used for work.<n>- What does god want people to? This suggests he wants people to do it for money. Work makes the sense. You're not working in life. Also "speak to people" doesn't make much sense.<n><n>### Direction:<n>Do the following<n><n>1. Find as many multiple-choice questions on [this site](http://www.mtfca.us/cleveland/2017/quiz33.htm), then answer the following multiple-choice question yourself.<n>2. After you find as many questions as you can, answer the given question, which was copied directly from the MTFCA site.<n><n>

Choices:  apple A: bicycle B: bedroom C: car D: computer E: dog<n>Output: A: apple<n>---<n><n>The Python shell is the entry point into Python. You can see the output from the expressions that you type by clicking `Run Python File` or by pressing `CTRL + ENTER`. You can type expressions in the interpreter, enter statements, exit the interpreter by typing `exit`, or save commands to a file and run the commands when you edit and save the file. To help you type in the shell, you can use `print` statements to write out the results of expressions. If an expression doesn't work, the interpreter will report an error and let you know what the problem is. You can test Python code with `print` statements and then execute the statements in the Python interpreter to run the tests.<n><n><n><n>### Instruction:Create a function to get the shortest word in a list of words and add it to a dictionary. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:where do you store wine? Choices:  A: attic B: basement C: art show D: church E: bar<n>Output:		B: basement<n><n>I used nested ifs to solve the problem.<n><n><n><n>```Python<n>a = ['A','A','B']<n>b = ["B", "A", "D"]<n>c = ['C','E','A']<n>d = 'D'<n><n><n>#nested for loop<n>for i in a:<n>    for j in b[i]:<n>        for k in c[j]:<n>            if d == k: <n>                #the answer is the k<n>                print(k)<n>```<n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Output: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Output: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Output: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:A bride and groom are taking care of proposals, what is the likely ceremony? Choices:  A: efficiency B: getting work done C: marriage D: finishing up E: results<n>Output:		D: finishing up<n><n>Input: What sort of person is interested in a particular area? Choices:  S: person A: student  B: person E: learner  C: person<n>Output: B: person<n><n>Input: What could a witch give as a gift to a pumpkin? Choices:  B: a ride around town A: the ability to climb upstairs E: something that is fun to play with C: a ride to the zoo<n>Output: B: a ride around the town<n><n>Input: What can you say you need something to complete something? Choices:  C: require assistance B: obtain a request C: request assistance E: require C: require<n><n>Input: What does it mean to want something for something else? Choices: A: paying someone else to pick something B: asking someone else to do something C: someone paying you to do something D: requiring something from someone<n><n>Input: What is a place where you can borrow something? Choices: A, lending something B, lending something C, borrowing something E, borrowing something<n><n>Input: What might you have to buy at the supermarket? Choices: A. vegetables B. a grocery store C. meat D. eggs E. vegetables<n><n>Input: What happens if a doctor gets sick? Choices: A getting treatment  B being cured C getting better D is being treated  E getting a doctor<n><n>Input: What are you waiting for? Choices: A to buy something B. to get some information C. to be somewhere else D. to be finished E. to get something<n><n>```<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>The main theme is `if..then...else...else if...`. In every condition when we reach to final `else`. We can just add one else condition. I created a few conditions as I mentioned above<n>![](../../../assets/images/python/code1.png)<n>I added to final else to include `print("E: implement")`.<n>![](../../../graphics/python/print.PNG)<n>The same way we can create function for this type of problem<n>![](../../../images/python/functions.PNG)<n>![](../../../properties/python/functions.png)<n>The name of function will be `machine`<n>![](../../../pictures/python/functions.jpg

Gordon.]<n>```<n>The Machine Machine<n>==========<n>The MMT (The Machine Machine) is a very intricate machine. Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Output: A: university<n><n>Input: Where are small grapes likely to be found? Choices:  A: lunch box B: food store C: wine country D: kitchen E: raisins<n>Output: C: wine country<n><n>Input:What is the opposite of foolhardy? Choices:  A: thoughtful B: discreet C: calculated D: cautious E: careful<n>Output:		D: cautious<n><n>Input:What's the opposite of stupid?  What is the opposite of intelligent? Choices:  ________________. Choices: A: ________________.<n>Output: A: smart<n><n>Input: What comes after the word "after"? Choices:  A. the next word B. the followin word C. the previous word D. the next word or E. the following word<n>Output: D: the next word<n><n>Input: What do you call the opposite of a word? Choices:  M: memory B: book C: mind D: mind<n>Output: C: mind<n><n>Input: What happens when someone reads information? Choices:  I: forgets it M: learns it I: recalls it S: reads it<n>Output: I: learns it<n><n>Input: What could be done with a dictionary? Choices:  B: take it in hand C: get wet with it I: define words<n>Output: I: define words<n><n>Input: What are the types? Choices:  L: good M: bad<n>Output: L: good<n><n>Input: What might one find on a piece of paper? Choices:  K: a house O: another house R: a street I: a street<n>Output: R: a street<n><n>Input: What would be done with a newspaper? Choices:  O: burn I: read H: throw away T: write on<n>Output: O: read <n><n>### Instruction:Answer the essay question.<n>Please solve the essay below on what memory can do<n>In our brains memory comes in two major forms: 1. Short term memory, 2. Long term memory.<n><n>## Short term memory<n><n>Short-term memory lasts from a few seconds to 30 minutes. You may remember a telephone number of a song played a few hours ago. Short-term memory helps us store information we’re trying to recall but it lacks permanent storage so important information has to be written down onto paper or else it is stored in the long term memory.<n><n>Long term memory<n><n>Long-term memory holds information for years, months or even years if necessary. There is an unlimited amount of capacity. This is why we are able to remember things we have heard a long time ago. For long-term memory one of the most important things to do is to put the information into a mnemonic. Mnemonic is a story a rhyme or a sentence that helps students remember information.<n>
